description:
A Monopoly clone set in the coastal town of Rostock-Warnemünde, Germany. As the game has been developed by a local radio station and sponsored by various Warnemünde entrepreneurs, the players have to acquire and trade company shares instead of streets.

The penalties for players ending their move on an already occupied field only increase with the number of company shares with identical colors; the concept of additional buildings such as hotels been dropped. Instead, this game features profit and loss statements that are triggered by certain fields. They change share values, resulting in players paying money into or getting money from a money pool. There are also pool cards triggering the profit and loss statements of shares of one color.
Another non-Monopoly concept is that of shortcut fields (Warnowtunnel, Scandlines ferry) that allow the players to quickly move over a section of the board for a small fee.

This educational game recreates Henry Ford's immense industrial complex outside of Detroit.  Players or teams compete to most efficiently produce Model A automobiles, while overcoming difficulties in production and management.  The game was produced in cooperation with the Henry Ford Museum & Greenfield Village.

This is a roll and move game featuring a car chase through the London streets. A lead car and 4 pursuit cars are represented by small, cast metal, car model playing pieces. Game has a similarity to Scotland Yard but with much more simple rules. An earlier version of this game is called "Bandit Chase across London" and listed elsewhere on BGG.

This is a revised version of the game "Numble" previously released in 1965, by Mag-Nif Inc., it contained flat tiles, tile holders, and a game board. It is a game similar to "Scrabble", but instead of connecting letters, the player is connecting numbers. This original version of "Tumble Numble" was released by Mag-Nif Inc. in 1966 it contained the dice, and instruction booklet. The box itself acted as a dice shaker. It was republished in 1969 by Selchow & Righter. For this edition, a score card, sand timer, and separate tumbler cup were also included. Selchow & Righter rereleased the original boardgame version of "Numble" in 1968, while their "Tumble Numble" version is called a "Portable Cube Edition".

{Dice included.}
Red numbers on cube, with (gold numbers): 1, 2, (3), 4, (5), 7
Blue numbers on cube: 1, 2, 3, 4, 7, 8
Green numbers cube: 1, 2, 3, 7, 8, 9
{8 cubes with Black numbers;}
{Blank side}, 0, 1, 7, 8, 9
0, 1, 2, 7, 8, 9
1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6
1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6
1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6
1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6
1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6
1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6

"THE OBJECT:
To compete for high score while placing numbered cubes in sequences that are divisible by three.

TO BEGIN:
Each player tumbles a cube.
The player with the highest value starts.
To start each round: place all eleven cubes in the Tumble Numble Tumbler,
the first player then tumbles five cubes into his hand (without looking at their values)
and passes these five cubes to the player on his left.
This occurs only at the beginning of each Round.
The remaining six cubes he tumbles upon the table and arranges as many as possible in a valid sequence.
After declaring the score, he passes the tumbler along with any cubes he was unable to use, to the player on his left.
The second player places his five cubes along with any unused cubes from the preceding player into the tumbler,
tumbles them upon the table and arranges his cubes as an extension or in cross-word fashion to the previously
played sequence.

BASIC STRATEGY
Create sequences that take best advantage of Bonus Cubes, particularly the double and triple sequence cube
so that the cube will be available to either you or your partner on succeeding plays.
Avoid making bonus cubes available to opponents.
Remember the Zero Cube freezes further play and is of considerable strategic value in this respect."

Arkadia is a game about building the city and castle of Arkadia.

Players use builders, cards, workers, and neutral workers to build houses in Arkadia. Houses are built with the seal of one of 4 families; this family gave the building order and will get the building player its seal.

These seals can be changed for victory points. But seals are subject to changing values. The growing castle (every time a house is built, players also build on the castle) has the 4 seals on it as well, which decides the value of each seal. The castle is also the game's timer: once the second layer is built, the last round starts. The player with the most gold wins.

Released: Essen 2006.

Online Play

     Yucata (turn-based)

Miniature rules for modern armored combat. Rules are design for playability with emphasis on keeping game play moving. Game rules include statistics on tanks from many different countries including USA, Israel, France, Germany, Britain, China and Russia. System is designed for use on 1/285 scale but can also be scaled to 10mm, 15mm and 20MM.
In this British card game, likely inspired by the children's song, everyone tries to get 10 teddy bears to come to his/her picnic. 54 cards show teddy bears, honey pots, food items and other objects.

Colin Meads Rugby Trivia New Zealand is a rugby board game designed for 2-6 players. It has 1,500 adult questions, 300 beginners questions and 300 childrens' questions so is great for the whole family!

How to play
Throw the die and move the number thrown along the board. Depending on what square is landed on as to whether a question is asked or not. If a question is asked players move ahead one space if correct and back 2 spaces if incorrect. There are penalty's bonus spaces and second chances.
Winner of the game is the one who gets to the finish first.

In this game by Roberto Fraga you are an alien from the planet Krakton. You've landed on planet earth, simply because you love the blue planet and its inhabitants. The object of this journey: a search for souvenirs.

By use of your legs, your breathing, your voice, your elbows and whatnot, you try to complete your mission. The challenges created by this game will seriously cause insane game nights.

Game art by Sofi, ages 8 and up, published: Essen 2006.

Mazel Tov!! You have been voted "Meshulach" (fund raiser" for your SHTEEBLE!  You must visit all 8 neighborhood Schteebles (4 in outer circle and 4 in inner circle), collect pledges, and return to your Home Schteeble in the inner circle.  After the first two players have returned home, both players count their money pledges and the one that has the most wins.

Players spin the spinner, move around, win money from the "Pushka," draw cards and learn loads of Yiddish!  Cards include "Flatbush Shteeble celebrates a "Siyum Shas," "Stare one player in the eye and say in a high, squeeky voice 'I vant Lukshin Keegel and I vant it RIGHT NOW!'  That player pays you $100", "Name all the Jewish months and get $100 from bank," and "Moishe Shmeel tied your tzizzis to your chair.  Pay $100 to pushka."

Ages 5 and over.

This game comes from a company called Chad Valley and was produced in the mid 1920's.  The object of the game was to shoot down and therefore sink your opponents sailing ships using balls fired from two working lead cannons.

Air Race is a game involving the delivery of mail around the world in the shortest time possible. The game is  for 2 - 4 players. Each player uses destination cards in order to determine where one needs to deliver the mail to. Finishing ones deliveries in the shortest amount of time is the goal of the game.  Rolling the dice is the method of movement. This is a Chad Valley game from the mid 1930's

Unusual game consisting of six character heads and two lithographed Yo-Yo style discs. The object is to place the disc over the head and roll it it round the perimeter back to the lithographed bee start position  without it falling off. That task is a pretty difficult thing to do. Characters are Jack (sailor HMS Watt.), Punch (Punch & Judy), Joey (Clown), Algy, Bertie and Colonel Bogey (cartoon or comic characters).

As the Avalanche Press website explains, Red Russia uses a similar system to Soldier Kings: The Seven Years War Worldwide in simulating the Russian Civil War. Players represent up to four factions: the Reds (Communists), Siberian Whites (monarchists), Southern Whites, or Northern Whites. Each turn represents three months, and the game begins in Summer of 1918 and concludes, should one player not win outright, in the Spring 1921 turn. This 3-4 hour game thus lasts a maximum of twelve turns.

Players command infantry and cavalry armies, and for some factions fleets and aircraft. Leaders assist these units in movement and combat over land areas and sea zones. Each land area is rated for the amount of money and manpower it generates each turn. Manpower represents not just fresh recruits for armies, but also the things made with human labor: food, uniforms, weapons and so on. Factions thus use manpower to rebuild forces, and money to finance their actions. Combat is conducted by rolling dice, one for each attack factor, with hits reducing them in strength or eliminating them outright. A good general lets you roll more dice. Each area is also rated for its garrison strength; to capture it, you have to defeat the garrison troops through siege (in addition to driving off any enemy armies there).

Finally, to keep the game from becoming too "Risk"-like, players can play various event cards.  Having the ability to fight through adversity makes one a powerful adversary in Red Russia.

"An Exciting Way to Discover Black Heritage!"

This is a well-produced game that tests the players' knowledge of famous black people, black history, and black culture, with a predominantly American focus.  The primary goal of the game is to score points by answering questions on the above subjects, with individual turn actions keyed by a basic roll-and-move mechanic.

The significant twist in the game is that each player takes one of twenty cards sets, each set consisting of 11 cards.  Ten are clue cards related to a single black historical figure or celebrity.  Another card in each set has the person's name and picture.  During the game, the other players have the opportunity privately or publicly hear the clues and try to guess the character.  The clues are divulged based on the players answers to toss-up questions on cards ("Words of Wisdom" and "Go Back to your Roots"), drawn when they land on the corresponding squares.  Other squares allow free guessing of secret identities, answering questions for additional points, and other more typical roll-and-move actions.  Points for answers/guesses are tallied on paper for as the game progresses.

This game appears to have a good balance between movement, deduction, and trivia mechanics.  An unfortunate rule is that players who have their secret identities guessed are then out of the game, so it would help to have the most obscure figure possible. (There were two of twenty I was completely unfamiliar with, and a couple more I needed a clue to recognize.)

There will not be much replay after all the IDs have been used...but if that happens the game will have largely succeeded in it primary educational goal.

The abstract game of Qwirkle consists of 108 wooden blocks with six different shapes in six different colors. There is no board, players simply use an available flat surface.

Players begin the game with six blocks. The start player places blocks of a single matching attribute (color or shape but not both) on the table. Thereafter, a player adds blocks adjacent to at least one previously played block. The blocks must all be played in a line and match, without duplicates, either the color or shape of the previous block.

Players score one point for each block played plus all blocks adjacent. It is possible for a block to score in more than one direction. If a player completes a line containing all six shapes or colors, an additional six points are scored. The player then refills his hand to six blocks.

The game ends when the draw bag is depleted and one player plays all of his remaining blocks, earning a six point bonus. The player with the high score wins.

Casino Six
The ultimate game of chance.

Casino Six brings the challenge and excitement of six real casino games into you home.  It's family fun for adults and older children - all in a simplified form, so even beginners can play.  For more experienced players (and bold novices!) authentic Craps and Roulette layouts can be found.  Games can be expanded to your liking.

Players advance through the Casino, trying their luck and testing their skill at six games in the following order:
Slots
Blackjack
Keno
Craps
Poker
Roulette

The object is to be the player who bankrupts all the others, winning all of the money.

Another expansion to the well known trivia game.
The questions all deal with topics like geography, destinations and other things related to traveling.

The box contains:
 - 2400 questions and answers on
 - 400 cards in
 - 2 plastic boxes.

Negotiate with the other players the purchase and the sale of goods and become the Great Negotiator. Each player is a merchant. At the beginning, it holds the monopoly of 2 goods and has gold coins. To gain, it must hold 8 different goods and at least 10 parts. For that, exchanges are organized between the players. Simple and original game, Négoces will astonish you by his subtlety. In this play the chance never intervenes, only your direction of the negotiation will enable you to gain.

From the publisher's website:

Once again, our unfortunate friends find themselves foreigners trapped within the frightful Fortress Furor of the fanged Prince Fieso who would, with felicity, see them flounder and faint.  These fine fighters could feasibly face their finish in this forbidding fortification, whose fearsome floors even now flow frighteningly from beneath their feet as the famished Furunkulus forages the fringes, fixing to feast on the foreigners’ flesh.  Forthwith, must our fighters fashion their flight from this foulest of fates!  But what’s this?  By the light of their fallow and flickering flares, our friends find the depths fraught with the most furious of fiends and the fiercest of freaks!  With fleet feet, the fearless foreigners follow these ferocious fellows through the fortress, with its multifarious footpaths and their frustrating forks, forging fervently forward toward freedom and fame.  Our fighters must not falter from whatever feud or fracas would foil their function: to finally furnish the forlorn Faerie Fabula her freedom from feckless Fieso’s fists!

Theme
Formidable Foes is a light-hearted dungeon crawl. The players all take the role of heroes competing with each other to amass the greatest hoard of treasure. They do this by exploring the dungeon and fighting monsters.

Goal
The goal is to collect as much gold as possible. The winner is the richest player.

Gameplay
On each turn, a player either moves twice; moves once and fights a monster; or collects 'power tokens' which allow a player to improve their dice rolls in subsequent turns. In the early part of the game, the monsters are fairly weak and easily defeated. Defeating a monster increases a character's 'wisdom' which allows them to fight and defeat ever-harder monsters. Fighting monsters involves rolling a dice and then adding power tokens to improve the roll if required.

This is a children's game.

The goal is to score points by getting strings of 3, 4, or 5 of your color in a straight line. The game comes with a board with the scoring for both variations written right on the playing surface.

One of the Avalon Hill games of the early 1990s was Blackbeard, a pirate game totally different from any others available because it simulated the actual life and careers of historical pirates, and how they went about their chosen professions.

Richard Berg has now taken the original and redesigned it, almost entirely, to bring it into line with what gamers like to see and play these days. All those pirates you loved:  Black Bart Roberts, Long Ben Avery, Ned Lowe, L'Ollonais, and, of course, Edward Teach (Blackbeard)--23 in all--are still there, as are the King's Commissioners sent out to stop them. However, the entire play system has been overhauled, and the result is a game that highlights and specializes in player interaction, with almost no down time for any player.

Players control individual pirates, using them to gain Victory Points by amassing booty and, even more importantly, earning Notoriety for their dastardly deeds;  seizing merchants with cargo ranging from useless paper to the monumental treasure of the Mughal emperors, attacking and sacking ports, fighting storms and scurvy, seeking safe haven in infamous pirate ports such as Tortuga and Madagascar, and, hopefully, using Letters of Marque to retire successfully.

At the same time that one player is doing all of this, the other players are playing their cards and seizing opportunities to harass the competing pirate.  There is a constant interplay among players, and you never know what might happen when you set out on any given mission.

We've simplified movement (no more hexes) and ship battles; we've expanded the use of Royal Navy warships; we've even added individual hostages! (Yes, there is a "Governor's Daughter".)

From Publisher:

The Monopoly Brand proudly presents the Atlanta Braves™ Collector’s Edition of America’s favorite board game. Braves fans now have the opportunity to buy, sell and trade Braves players, coaches, announcers and team icons. Features legendary Braves players like Hank Aaron, John Smoltz and Andruw Jones. Includes six collectible pewter tokens: Braves hat, batter, pitcher, ball in glove, Georgia dog and the Atlanta Braves tomahawk. With some of the all-time greatest Major League Baseball players and a bright future ahead, the Braves continue to make for exciting play in this timeless game of risk taking and deal making. Bankrupt your opponents in a quest to own the Braves.

This is a 'press your luck' kind of dice game...

Each person is given two dice (with numbers 1 to 4, two sides have 1's, two sides have 2's), and some chips to begin.  Some chips are left in the center to form the 'pot'.

On a person's turn, he/she begins by rolling the 2 dice, examining the sum of the two numbers.

If they add up to 2, that person has been 'stung', and a chip is given to the pot, and play passes to the next player.

If they add up to 8, that person has rolled a 'sting', and gets to take 2 chips from the pot, and play passes to the next player.

If they add up to anything else, that person MUST roll again and try to roll a number equal to, or higher, than the sum of the first roll.  At this point ANYONE else playing can also try to roll a sum equal to or higher.  Anyone who succeeds gets 2 chips from the pot, anyone who fails loses one.  If the active player ends up going it alone, and succeeds, his/her winnings are doubled.  Losings are never doubled.

Play ends at a specific number of chips or when the pot is exhausted.

On The Green Golf is a hole-by-hole simulation that brings together the detail of a shot-by-shot game with the quick-play of a round-by-round game.

Golfers are rated for their ability to reach greens in regulation, going for the green, sand saves, and eagles.  Holes are rated for their effect on scoring, and have been painstakingly rated to account for the major hazards and features that will challenge golfers.

The game includes an optional (but highly recommended) weather system that modifies dice rolls for weather and wind, pin placements, and user setting of rough (although a die roll could also make that determination).

There is also a QuickPlay system that allows players the ability to play a round in just three dice rolls for each golfer.  This gives players the opportunity to complete entire tournaments in a reasonable amount of time.

And the best part about the QuickPlay system is that you can mix-and-match the three QuickPlay options (full round, nine-hole version, and six-hole version) to QuickPlay some of each round, then switch to the regular game to play out exciting finishes.

The game comes with the following:

-- 2005 men's golfer set (202 cards)
-- Six courses (Augusta, Baltusrol, The Belfry, Pinehurst, Sawgrass, and St. Andrews)
-- Weather and Course Condition Cards
-- Suspense Charts
-- QuickPlay Charts for all six courses
-- Rules

The game is available in two formats:

1) E-Game Format via Hot Stove Games:  We send you the files, you print the components using your own equipment or local print shop.  E-mail us at hotstovegames@yahoo.com for ordering information.

2) Printed Format via Downey Games:  You receive a full-color, printed version of the game with die-cut golfer and course cards, sent to you in a sturdy storage box.  Check out the game under "Board Games" at www.downeygames.com

Conquest is a strategic space exploration and conquest (naturally) game for 2-4 players.  Each player starts in a system at a corner of the map and expands outward from there.

Each player represents a different spacefaring race/organization - the Terrans, the Olso Empire, the Federation (changed to the Confederation in the second edition), and the Tholians (changed to the Lothians in the second edition).  Each has a different set of units they can build, with varying capabilities - ships are rated for space combat, ground (bombardment) combat, drive system, and what kind of damage they take from the various combat results.

When a star is explored a card is drawn which determines the class of the inhabitable world found there and, if inhabited, its attitude to each of the players.  In addition to the attitude the value of each kind of planet varies by player.

There are three different long-range movement systems in the game - warp drive, jump drive (similar to warp drive but much less accurate), and stargates, which have to be built and carried to where you want to use them.  Each player uses one of the three systems for their ships.

The second edition, in addition to changing the names of two of the races, changed some of the ship designs which were similar to Star Trek and Star Wars ships. It also changed the name of the game to The Conquest and Exploration of Space.

Contents: 1 Wok, 4 Chopsticks, 4 Bowls, Play Food
Object of the game: When the wok is empty, the player with the most food is the winner.

Requires 2 AA batteries.  Turn switch on and the wok will start spinning.  Use your chopsticks to pick up food from the wok and place into your bowl.

From the box:

CONTENTS: 4 Playing Boards, 36 Cards.

HOW TO PLAY: Each player takes a playing board and the smaller cards are placed face down on the table. The youngest player starts by turning over one of the cards and matching it with one of the characters on his playing board. If he cannot, he leaves the card face upwards on the table. The next player may then take this card or selects another. Play continues; should a player turn over a card the he already has, play passes to the next player.

The winner is the first player to cover all his characters on his playing board.

FOR OLDER CHILDREN: If a player picks up a card he does not need he replaces the card face downwards on the table. The other players then have to remember where that card was replaced if they need that particular character.

Inside the box:

- 4 boards, each with the letters of the alphabet
- 100 subject cards 
- timer
- 110 chips

Idea of the game:

To fill one's own board as quick as possible. Player gets a subject and timer starts. Player tries to say as many words as possible from the given subject in given time. Simultaneously the player covers up the letter on his board with a chip. For example: if the subject is animals in jungle, the players says "ape" and covers letter 'A' in the board. Then the player says "elephant" and covers the letter 'E' and so on.

It sounds easy but the time is limited.

From the Publisher:

“Let’s Go, Go-Go White Sox!” 2005 marks the year the White Sox™ brought a World Series® Championship back to Chicago and ended an 88 year drought! The MONOPOLY® Brand is proud to present the Chicago White Sox World Series Edition of the world’s most famous board game. This collector’s game captures and brings to life the glory of the 2005 World Series Champions, the Chicago White Sox, featuring photos from the 2005 playoffs. Some of the greatest moments in playoff history have been forever preserved like defeating the defending World Champions Boston Red Sox™ and winning 4 straight games against the Angels™. Players such as Paul Konerko, Mark Buehrle and Jon Garland make for exciting play in this classic game of risk taking and deal making. The tried and true White Sox fan can now buy, sell and trade the best of the 2005 White Sox, in an effort to own and control one of the most famed seasons in White Sox team history.

You can download this application Bulltricker 2D, here http://www.bulltricker.com/
It's 100% FREE for WINDOWS, MAC, LINUX !

HAVE FUN !!

NEW !!! You can play online, using the Bulltricker 2D app downloadable from our site, and playing message by message through our site chat. It's 100% free (for now).
This application (Bulltricker 2D) manages the rules of the game. When you have taken your turn, you must copy the coordinates of your move which are displayed by the application, [simply click on the "COPY" button (in the application), this memorizes the coordinates in plain text], and return to the chat to send these coordinates to your opponent by doing a simple "right click" and "Paste" and "Send".

Conversely, when you receive the message of the coordinates of the move that your opposing player sent you in the chat, then "select" just the message of these coordinates (by just selecting the coordinates, that is to say from the first letter or number on the left and up to the last letter or number on the right) and doing a simple "right click" + "copy". Come back to the application, and doing a simple "right click" in the field ([______ ] [Apply]) and the coordinates will immediately be entered in this field, then you just have to click on the button "APPLY", and your opponent's move is immediately reproduced on your game (because the application manages the moves, and the coordinates of the moves).

You can play entire games for as long as possible and as many times as you want. Simply by using our chat and our 2D Bulltricker app.
It's completely free at the moment.

This 2D application for the Bulltricker game has just been launched.
It's simple and modest but perfectly playable and functional.
Everything works perfectly, so it's perfect for playing full parties!

[ Download here >> http://www.bulltricker.com/ ]
Another point, this application also allows you to play:
- 1 VS 1 : Game by Local network !
- 1 VS 1 : Game on the same central unit, in front of the same screen (1 vs 1), the display changes direction to adapt the correct direction of the pieces for the player who has the move.
- 1 VS 1 : Game by text message (chat, mail, sms) this application allows you to play remotely by exchanging a message of the coordinates of the moves played.
After playing your turn, the application generates the message to send to your opponent, with a single click, it's to copy, just paste it in the chat or email or sms.
It also allows you to insert and reproduce the coordinate message you received, with a single click, and it analyzes the coordinates of the move, and if it is correct, the application reproduces your opponent's move on your game. You may then take your turn. And so on...

This game is a mix between chess and checkers, this rules are freely available here >> http://www.bulltricker.com/ [English and French ].
Let's go over a brief overview :

>> Aim of the game : Surround the opposing King between 4 pieces (Queen or Pawn) with a minimum of one of your own pieces.

>> PIECES : 
The King : can't capture/can't be captured/can't jump over pieces and no other piece can jump over the king.
The pawn : you have vertical and horizontal pieces, can capture other pieces. Moves 1 space.
The queen : again : you have vertical and horizontal pieces. May move the full length.

Everything is explained here: http://www.bulltricker.com/

Thank you for coming and checking it out!
You can play as much as you want, it's free, and it's a game that both chess players and checkers really like, because it's a great strategy game for two players.

The goal of the game is to complete a circuit in Belgium (for example the gastronomical, sports, touristic, casino or economical circuit) faster than your opponents by traveling from city to city. This is done either by foot, bicycle or car. Money can be earned (to buy a bicycle or car) or lost during the game.
This game from Glevum Games of Gloucester England is a simple roll (spin) and move game similar to many of the times. It features lead racing boats. The game comes from the mid 1930's.

Four player game. Game comes with four small race car playing pieces. The playing board is divided into 100 squares with a track running through them.  Some squares have advantage, some squares have penalties.  Roll and move around this track. First player to the finish line wins.

Four player game. Comes with a triple-fold board that shows a map of the World.  Progress around the board is determined by advantage and penalty stops. There is no indication of who the designed this game.

This is a British game from the 1950's or 60's. It originated from a T.V. show of the same name starring Marion Ryan. The game comes with a 33rpm record with a few bars of 96 tunes; the object for the three to twelve players is to Spot the Tune. It reminds one of the American TV show called NAME THAT TUNE (I can name that song in 4 notes ...... etc.).

Who can change sides with their whole team the quickest?

The crux of the matter: at the end of the game all figures should be standing in exactly the same position but at the other end of the board. Dark or light -- the players' figures intermingle, seemingly randomly on their journey across the board, and they are allowed to jump in any direction that will help them. Using clever tactics helps: the little moves could open up a broader and surprising new perspective. A tactical jumping game for two capricious strategists.

Imaginative town planners are needed here to use the many elegant buildings to form imposing squares.

When a new enclosed square is formed by the skillful placement or sliding along of the buildings, the successful architect can place a monument in the center of it. Spatial imagination together with well thought out planning are positive advantages in this game for 2 people.

"Satisfactory" is a card game that bring the best and worst parts of "White Collar Work" into an interactive card game.

Each player manages a hand of cards consisting of "Hours", "Ladders", "Back-Stabbing" and "Special" cards. On each turn you pay "hours" to place down "ladder" cards trying to climb the corporate ladder to the top. Beware though, as other players can spend their hours to play "Back-stabbing cards trying to either demote your or take credit for your work.

8 random "CEO" cards alter the game dynamics by creating changes and effects to all players.

Each round is considered a week of work, and after 8 weeks the game is over. The "Worker" with the most Ladder Points wins the game.

This is a NON collectible game for 2-6 players for fast paced card action.

On the afternoon of October 3rd, 1993, a combined force of American Rangers and Delta Force operators dropped into an area of Mogadishu, Somalia, controlled by notorious clan warlord Mohamed Farrah Aidid and his loyal militiamen. The Americans’ objective was to capture two of Aidid’s high-ranking lieutenants and get out, but the Aidid and his men had different plans. Two destroyed Black Hawks, 100 American casualties, and twenty-four hours later, the “one-hour” mission ended.

Day of Heroes lets gamers rope down from a Black Hawk with a Chalk of Rangers or step off a Little Bird with Delta Force operators onto the mean streets of Mogadishu, filled with the smell of noxious smoke rising from burning roadblocks, a signal calling Somali militiamen to arms. Play nine scenarios, including the campaign-length scenario, “Day of Heroes”. The Battle of Mogadishu is on, and you can be a part of it.

UPDATE: All of our manuals and guides can be Downloaded, Viewed, and even printed right from our LnLP Online Library: We now have an Online Library of all, well almost all of our manuals.  We add some every few weeks.  You can find all the LnLT manuals at the link below.

LnLP Online Library: http://library.lnlpublishing.com/

A Master Stroke: The Battle for Meiktila deals with the British offensive to the railroad town of Meiktila in Burma and the subsequent Japanese counterattack. This was a fight characterized by the bold move made by the 17th Indian Division to abandon their supply lines to take Meiktila, unhinging the Japanese defense line. Relying on air supply to hold out against Japanese attacks, the 17th Indian Division ultimately prevailed.

Scale: Battalion
Game Turn: 1 day/turn

A simple game published by the German City of Paderborn. By playing the players get to know a little bit about the city and its shops.
During each players' turn they roll a six-sided dice to move along a game-board depicting a map of Paderborn. At certain spaces players can acquire cards of the shops or they can go sightseeing by following the instructions on the back of the card. Sometimes there is only information written, sometimes you have to pay an amount of money or at other times you may earn some cash.
The game ends when the last player reaches the finish space with his playing piece. The winner is the person who has acquired the most sightseeing and/or shop cards.

EQUID is a captivating board game which brings you the thrill of a day at the races. Place your bets on a horse and try to make it win using a mixture of general knowledge, tactics and judgment.
EQUID takes the form of a race in which any player can move any horse without knowing who has bet on which. At the start of the game the players study the cards they have been dealt and place secret bets: either a straight win bet or a combination bet. Each player in turn answers general knowledge questions about horses, and can play a card to accelerate a horse, until two horses have crosses the finishing line.
The wide variety of cards and the color and position of the horses give the players unlimited scope for tactics and last-minute gallops to the finishing post !
The appeal of EQUID is that the game is a mixture of bluff, astute card playing, tactics and general knowledge, without forgetting an element of chance to spice up the game and create an enjoyable atmosphere and some unforgettable moments !
The game covers every aspect of a horse and its universe, with over 1100 questions about ethology, anatomy, racing, techniques, equipment, health, feeding, sporting events... to test your knowledge and bring you a wealth of interesting facts and amusing anecdotes !

From the publisher's website:
"The best selling book is now an
at-home experience like no other!

“Your Best Life Now” by Joel Osteen has sold over 3 million copies and has been on the New York Times and Publisher’s Weekly Best Seller list for over 50 consecutive weeks. The game enables players to step beyond the one-on-one nature of the book and feel, touch, and live Joel’s 7 Steps To Living At Your Full Potential with your friends and family. Your Best Life Now: The Game is an entertaining and educational way to take inventory of yourself and accountability of your actions. Climb the mountain as you

• Enlarge Your Vision

• Develop a Healthy Self Image

• Discover the Power of your Thoughts and Words

• Let Go of the Past

• Find Strength Through Adversity

• Live To Give

And • Choose to Be Happy

Each new plateau represents a challenge and a chance to open up and experience these steps first hand as you learn to live Your Best Life Now.

The Battle of Hastings was the most decisive Norman victory in the Norman conquest of England. On October 14, 1066, the Normans of Duke William of Normandy (aka "Guillaume Le Conquérant" in French, "William the Conqueror" in English) defeated the Anglo-Saxon army led by King Harold II.

1967 3M TEACH KEY Reading and Spelling. Scarce 3M EduPLAYtional game. Triangular shaped box. This game is in the same series as Egghead and Chicken.

Includes 2 packs of 24 key cards (48 total), the house board, box, and set of keys. I do not know if add-on card sets were available, although it is possible.

Players ages 5-8 insert the key into the correct missing letter hole of each word in order to correctly spell and thus unlock the word.

description of the game from LudoArt:

Chicago, 1925. It is the time of Prohibition. 4 opposing gangs, each with 9 gangsters want to bring the city under their control. By playing out rows, each of which consist of 6 gangsters, players try to gain a majority through their most valuable gangsters. But careful! To gain powerful positions, sometimes sharpshooting is needed. The goal of the game is to become the most powerful of all, Al Capone. Tactics, strategy and cold-bloodedness will be required if you want to be celebrated as the boss of bosses in this game.

What gives the game its flair, apart from the real metal munitions, is the deft touch of the illustrator as well as court artist Robert Nippoldt. From corrupt mayor William Hale "Big Bill" Thompson to Boss of Bosses Al "Scarface" Capone, all of the major gangsters of this lead-filled time are represented. The well-known portraits are taken from the eponymous book "Gangster. The Bosses of Chicago" by Robert Nippoldt, and give the game a sheen of authenticity. The book has received awards from the German Designer Club, Buchkunst Fund as well as the Red Dot Design Award 2006.

Expanded by: Gangster: Der Clou.

Every player undertakes a road trip through the USA. While traveling the player's goal is to visit all locations as fast as possible. To prove this to the other players every player has to get a postcard from each location.
The players have to answer questions whenever they don't land on a location, but on an open field. The cards have questions divided into three categories: easy, medium, hard. All questions are in English and you have to answer in English (note that this is a German game).
If a player hits a special location, he takes the postcard from that location, reads it out aloud and places it in front of him. Whoever visits all 15 locations first wins.

A vanity press publication from New Zealand in 2000.

From the box: Search the Egyptian sands for ancient treasures, face terrible monsters, treacherous traps and curses. Employ dastardly schemes to profit from your opponents. Steal their treasure, assassinate their guides, corrupt their bodyguards, dabble in the ancient arts of magic... But watch your back! In the desert everyone is digging for treasure. Trust no-one, not even your camel!

From the box:

It's easy to get started:  Just play a Number 1.  Then build a pile from Number 1 to Number 5.  BUT BE CAREFUL!  An opponent may get you with a DOWN-A-DOT-O card, which will send your pile a tumbling!... Until you counter with a ZAP-A DOWN-A-DOT-O!  Then play it safe with ADD-A-DOT-O NO DOUBT-O, and maybe you will win!
